articles.headline: F.A.A. Tests Ways to Detect Runway Junk
articles.snippet: A sensor is being tested by the Federal Aviation Administration to detect debris that can damage airplane engines on takeoff or even lead to plane crashes.
articles.abstract: A sensor is being tested by the Federal Aviation Administration to detect debris that can damage airplane engines on takeoff or even lead to plane crashes.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON  At the edge of Logan International Airport’s Runway 15-right, a technician watched a yellow sensor slowly scan back and forth across the pavement. He waited until it was pointed away from him and, like a man dodging a lawn sprinkler, he rushed to the middle of the 150-foot-wide runway, tossed a plastic pen onto the surface, and dashed back.

articles.headline: Court Says Texas Illegally Seized Sect’s Children
articles.snippet: The ruling abruptly threw the largest custody case in recent American history into turmoil.
articles.abstract: The ruling abruptly threw the largest custody case in recent American history into turmoil.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON  A Texas appeals court ruled on Thursday that the state had illegally seized up to 468 children from their homes at a polygamist ranch in West Texas. The decision abruptly threw the largest custody case in recent American history into turmoil.

articles.headline: Iraq Spending Ignored Rules, Pentagon Says
articles.snippet: An audit of $8.2 billion spent on contractors in Iraq found that almost none of the payments followed federal rules.
articles.abstract: An audit of $8.2 billion spent on contractors in Iraq found that almost none of the payments followed federal rules.
articles.lead_paragraph: A Pentagon audit of $8.2 billion in American taxpayer money spent by the United States Army on contractors in Iraq has found that almost none of the payments followed federal rules and that in some cases, contracts worth millions of dollars were paid for despite little or no record of what, if anything, was received.

articles.headline: Junta Offers Showcase Camps, but Most Burmese Lack Aid
articles.snippet: Several days after Than Shwe, the leader of the military junta, visited a camp with relief supplies, aid is still held up.
articles.abstract: Several days after Than Shwe, the leader of the military junta, visited a camp with relief supplies, aid is still held up.
articles.lead_paragraph: HLINETHAYA RELIEF CAMP, Myanmar  The 68 blue tents are lined up in a row, with a brand-new water purifier and boxes of relief supplies, stacked neatly but as yet undelivered and not even opened. “If you don’t keep clean, you’ll be expelled from here,” a camp manager barked at families in some tents.

articles.headline: Medtronic Settles a Civil Lawsuit on Allegations of Medicare Fraud
articles.snippet: Two insiders had said Kyphon, a unit of Medtronic, improperly persuaded hospitals to keep people overnight for a simple outpatient procedure to repair small fissures of the spine.
articles.abstract: Two insiders had said Kyphon, a unit of Medtronic, improperly persuaded hospitals to keep people overnight for a simple outpatient procedure to repair small fissures of the spine.
articles.lead_paragraph: A unit of Medtronic defrauded Medicare of hundreds of millions of dollars, according to a civil lawsuit that was unsealed Thursday and simultaneously settled with the Justice Department.

articles.headline: The Same Old Song on High Gas Prices
articles.snippet: In what has become a regular show in the hearing rooms on Capitol Hill, oil company executives took a second day of lashings over the rising price of gasoline.
articles.abstract: In what has become a regular show in the hearing rooms on Capitol Hill, oil company executives took a second day of lashings over the rising price of gasoline.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Representative Debbie Wasserman Schultz peered down at the executives from the nation’s biggest oil companies, arrayed before the House Judiciary Committee like five targets in a carnival dunk tank, wearing dark suits and ties instead of swim trunks.

articles.headline: At Supreme Court, 5-to-4 Rulings Fade, but Why?
articles.snippet: So far this term, with 35 cases decided with full opinions, there has been only a single 5-to-4 decision.
articles.abstract: So far this term, with 35 cases decided with full opinions, there has been only a single 5-to-4 decision.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Where have all the 5-to-4 decisions gone?

articles.headline: As Market Shifts, Ford Sees Profit Fleeing
articles.snippet: Rising gas prices and falling truck sales prompted the automaker to announce production cuts and retreat on its goal to become profitable by 2009.
articles.abstract: Rising gas prices and falling truck sales prompted the automaker to announce production cuts and retreat on its goal to become profitable by 2009.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT The budding turnaround at the Ford Motor Company has stalled amid rising gas prices and falling truck sales.

articles.headline: As Race Wanes, Talk of Clinton as No. 2 Grows
articles.snippet: Friends say that Bill Clinton has spoken of the idea of his wife as Barack Obama’s running mate.
articles.abstract: Friends say that Bill Clinton has spoken of the idea of his wife as Barack Obama’s running mate.
articles.lead_paragraph: While Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and her advisers insist that she is determined to win the Democratic nomination, friends of the couple say that former President Bill Clinton, for one, has begun privately contemplating a different outcome for her: As Senator Barack Obama’s running mate.
articles.byline: By Patrick Healy and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Fund Fees Revisited in Court
articles.snippet: A federal appeals court decides against a confusing law on mutual fund management fees.
articles.abstract: A federal appeals court decides against a confusing law on mutual fund management fees.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 1970, Congress decided that there was too little price competition in the mutual fund industry and amended the law to allow fund investors to file suits claiming that management fees were excessive.
